baseline_groups.claim_summary: Product creation rates (extensive margin, EXTENS) are procyclical: a 1pp increase in total product group growth is associated with a 0.30pp increase in the extensive margin creation rate, estimated via panel FE on product groups (rpg) with sample restricted to |TOTAL|<0.2.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 7, Column 1. Coefficient 0.2985 (SE 0.0197, p<0.0001). N=1815, R2(within)=0.120. This is the primary result of the paper for the publicly available data.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Product destruction rates (DISSAP) are countercyclical but much less responsive than creation: a 1pp increase in total growth is associated with a 0.05pp decrease in the disappearance rate.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 7, Column 2. Coefficient -0.0529 (SE 0.0126, p<0.001). Much smaller magnitude than the EXTENS coefficient, establishing the asymmetry between creation and destruction.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Net product creation (NET = EXTENS - DISSAP) is strongly procyclical, with product creation dominating the extensive margin response to growth.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 7, Column 3. Coefficient 0.3514 (SE 0.0185, p<0.0001). NET = EXTENS - DISSAP mechanically, so the NET coefficient approximately equals EXTENS coef minus DISSAP coef.

global_notes: Paper is 'Product Creation and Destruction: Evidence and Price Implications' by Broda & Weinstein (AER 2010). The specification search focuses on Table 7, which uses publicly available panel data (EXTDISCOM.dta, 123 product groups x 16 quarters). Tables 1-6 and 8-9 require proprietary ACNielsen scanner data and cannot be replicated. The remaining 6 baseline specs (baseline/extens_expansion, baseline/dissap_expansion, baseline/net_expansion, baseline/extens_contraction, baseline/dissap_contraction, baseline/net_contraction) are Table 7 columns 4-9, which split the sample by expansions vs contractions. These are classified as core sample restrictions rather than separate baseline groups because they test the same relationship on subsamples. The food CPI analysis (specs food/*) uses a different dataset (Food_rc_cpi.dta) testing a distinct claim about CPI bias, so these are classified as non-core (different outcome/analysis). Some specs are exact duplicates: functional/quadratic = controls/fe_quadratic, functional/abs_total_treat = treatment/abs_total, functional/net_quadratic = controls/net_fe_quadratic. The spec controls/net_controlling_common has a coefficient of ~1.0 with essentially zero SE, which is a mechanical identity (NET + COMMON = TOTAL, so controlling for COMMON makes the TOTAL coefficient exactly 1). There are 93 total specifications.
